Play details
The fair maid of the west, part ii. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1631. Date first performed: 1630-1631?

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

sp.speaker: Tota.
sp.p:
It must not, may not, shall not be endured:
Left we for this our Country? to be made
A mere neglected Lady here in Fesse,
A slave to others, but a scorn to all?
Can womanish ambition, heat of blood,
Or height of birth brooke this, and not revenge?
Revenge? on whom? on mighty Mullisheg?
We are not safe then; On the English stranger?
And why on her, when there is no apprehension
That can in thought pollute her innocence?
Yet something I must do. What? nothing yet?
Nor must we live neglected; I should doubt
I were a perfect woman, but degenerate
From mine own sex if I should suffer this:
I have a thousand projects in my brain,
But can bring none to purpose.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Called your Majesty?

sp.speaker: Tota.
sp.p:
No, yet I think I did; be gone, yet stay.
Will not this misshaped Embryo grow to form?
Not yet? nor yet?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: I attend your highness pleasure.

sp.speaker: Tota.
sp.p:
It is perfect, and I have it,
I am ambitious but to think upon it,
And if it prove as I have fashioned it,
I shall be trophied ever.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: I wait still.

sp.speaker: Tota.
sp.p:
The King no way in peril, she secure,
None harmed, all pleased, I sweetly satisfied,
And yet revenged at full. Brain, I for this
Will wreathe thee in a glorious arch of gold,
stuck full of Indian gems. But Tota, whom
Wilt thou employ in this? the Moors are treacherous,
And them we dare not trust.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: You need not me.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Say, where is the King?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: In the Presence.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
Distempered late, and strangely humorous,
The cause none can conjecture.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Send in his sweet heart,
And were his own heart double ribbed with brass,
Yet she would search the inmost of his thoughts.
No, it is not her on whom I build my project.
Is the King upon his entrance?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
It is thought he is,
If so, this sudden strange distemperature
Hath not his purpose altered.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
You have now leave
To leave us and attend the King,

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: I shall.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
If any of the English Ladies train
Come in your way, you may request them hither,
Say, we would question some things of their country.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Madam, I shall.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Then on to your attendance, what we must,
We will work by the English, these we dare not trust.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: It is the Queen's pleasure you attend her.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
The Queen speak with me? Can you tell the
business? A murrain of these barbers of Barbary, they
have given me a receipt, that scape the colic as well as
I can, I shall be sure never to be troubled with the stone.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Yonder she walks. I leave ye.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Now sir, you are of England?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: And I think you are a witch.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: How sirrah?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
A foolish proverb we use in our country, which
to give you in other words, is as much as to say, You have
hit the nail on the head.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
And servant to the English Elizabeth,
So great in Court by mighty Mullisheg,
You follow her?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I must confess I am not her Gentleman usher to
go before her, for that way as the case stands with me
now, I can do her but small pleasure, I do follow her.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
You have seen both nations, England and our
Fesse, how do our people differ?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Our countrymen eat and drink as yours do
for all the world, open their eyes when they would see,
and shut them again when they would sleep: when
they go they set one leg before another, and gape when
their mouths open, as yours eat when they have stomachs,
scratch when it itcheth: only I hold our nation
to be the cleanlier.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Cleanlier, wherein?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Because they never sit down to meat with such
foul hands and faces.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: But how your Ladies and choice Gentlewomen?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
You shall meet some of them sometimes as fresh
as flowers in May, and as fair as my Mistress, and within
an hour the same Gentlewoman as black as yourself,
or any of your Morians.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Can they change faces so? not possible: show me
some reason for it.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: When they put on their masks.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Masks, what are they?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Please you to put off yours, and I will tell you.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
we wear none but that which nature hath bestowed
on us, and our births give us freely.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
And our Ladies wear none but what the shops
yield, and they buy for their money.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Canst thou be secret to me Englishman?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Yes, and chaste too, I have taken a medicine
for it.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Be fixed to me in what I shall employ thee,
Constant and private unto my designs,
More grace and honour I will do to thee,
Than ere thou didst receive from Mullisheg.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Grace and honour? his grace and honour was to
take away some part, and she would honour me to take
away all: I will see you damned as deep as the black father
of your generation the devil first.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Mistake me not.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Nay if you were with child with a young
princely devil, and had a mind to anything that is here,
I would make you lose your longing.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Sure this fellow is some sot.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Grace and honour, quotha.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: How now Clem, whither in such post haste?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
There, if you will have any grace and honour,
you may pay for it as dear as I have done; 'sfoot I have
little enough left, I would fain carry home something into
my own country.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Why, what is the matter? I prithee stay.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
No, Lieutenant you shall pardon me, not I, the
room is too hot for me: I will be gone, do you stay at your
own peril: I will be no longer a prodigal, I will keep what
I have.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
This should have better sense, I will next prove
him.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Excuse me mighty Princess, that my boldness
Hath pressed thus far into your privacies.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
You no way have offended; nay, come near,
We love to grace a stranger.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
It was my ignorance,
And no pretended boldness.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
I have observed you
To be of some command amongst the English,
Nor make I question but that you may be
Of fair revenues.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: A poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: We will make thee rich; spend that.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Your graces bounty
Exceeds what merit can make good in me:
I am your highness servant.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Let that jewel be worn as our high favour.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
'Sfoot I think
This Queen is in love with me. Madam, I shall.

sp.speaker: Tot.
Ruff.
sp.p: Doubtless it is so, and I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Nay we shall take it ill
To give ourselves so amply to your knowledge,
And you not use us.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Use us, now upon my life she is caught:
What, courted by a Queen? a royal Princess;
Where were your eyes Besse, that you could not see
These hidden parts and mysteries, which this Queen
Hath in my shape observed? it is but a fortune
That I was born to, and I thank heaven for it.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: May I trust you?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
With your life, with your honour.
I will be as private to you as your heart
Within your bosom, close as your own thoughts.
I will brag of this in England, that I once
Was favourite to a Queen, my royal mistress.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
If what you have already promised you will make good,
I will prove so.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Madam, let this,

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: This kiss.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: This fool, this ass, this insolent gull.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Why, did not your grace mean plainly?

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: In what, sir?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Did you not court me?

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
How, that face?
Thinkest thou I could love a Monkey, a Baboon?
Know, were I mounted in the height of lust,
And a mere prostitute, rather than thee
I would embrace, one, name but that creature
That thou dost think most odious.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Pardon me Lady,
I humbly take my leave.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Have I given you your description I pray, sir,
Be secret in it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
I shall be loath to tell it,
Or publish it to any.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Yet you are not gone:
Know then you have incurred
The Kings wrath first, our high displeasure next,
The least of which is death; yet will you grow
More near to us, and prove loyal unto my present purposes.
I will not only pardon you what is past.
But multiply my bounties.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I am your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Be free, there is nothing can be called offence,
But that in thee we pardon.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I am fast.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
And yet a free man: I am injured highly,
And thou must aid me in my just revenge.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Were it to combat the most valiantest Moore,
That ever Fesse, Morocco, or Argiers bred,
I for your sake would do it.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
We seek nor blood,
Nor to expose thee to the least of danger:
I am modest, and what I dare not trust my own tongue with,
Or thoughts, I will boldly give unto thine ears,
List: Do you shake your head, say, Is it done already?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Wrong my friend?

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Do you cast doubts or dangers? Is not our life,
Our honour all in your hand, and will you lavish us.
Or scant that bounty should crown you with excess.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I will pause upon it.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Is not your life ours by your insolence? have not
we power to take it?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Say no more, I will do it.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: But may I hope.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
I have cast all doubts, and know how it may be
compassed.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: There is more gold, your secrecy that is all I crave.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
To prove myself in this just cause I have,
An honest man, or a pernicious knave.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Take the advantage of this night.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
I shall expect fair end,
All doubts are cast.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: So make a Queen thy friend.

div2.stage: Enter Mullisheg, Ioffer, and Alcade, Spencer, Goodlack, Besse, and the rest.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
All music is harsh, command these discords cease,
For we have war within us.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Mighty King,
What is it offends your highness?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Nothing Besse:
Yet all things do: O, what did I bestow,
When I gave her away.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: The Queen attends you.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Let her attend.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Aye, King, neglected still,
My just revenge shall wound, although not kill.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
I was a traitor to my own desires,
To part with her so slightly: what, no means
To alter these proceedings?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Strange disturbances.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What might the project be?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p:
May it please your Highness, shall the Mask go forward,
That was intended to grace this jovial night?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
We will have none,
Let it be treason held
To any man that shall but name our pleasure,
Or that vain word, delight: The more I gaze,
The more I surfeit; and the more I strive
To free me from these fires, I am deeper wrapped:
In flames I burn.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Your discontent, great Prince, takes from us all
The edge of mirth: these nuptial joys that should
Have swelled our souls with all the sweet varieties
Of apprehensive wishes, with your sadness
Grows dull and leaden: they have lost their taste
In this your discontent all pleasures lose their sweetness.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Mighty Fesse,
Hath any ignorant neglect in us
Bred these disturbances?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Offence and you
Are like the warring elements, opposed.
And Fesse, why a king, and not command thy pleasure?
Is she not within our kingdom? nay, within our palace,
And therefore in our power: is she alone
That happiness that I desire on earth?
Which since the heavens have given up to mine hands,
Shall I despise their bounty? and not rather
Run through a thousand dangers, to enjoy
Their prodigal favours? dangers? tush, there is none:
We are here amidst our people, walled with subjects round,
And danger is our slave: besides, our war
Is with weak woman. O, but I have sworn
And sealed to her safe conduct; What of that?
Can a king swear against his own desires,
Whose welfare is the sinews of his Realm?
I should commit high treason gainst myself,
Not to do that might give my soul content,
And satisfy my appetite with fullness. Alcade.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Rides the English Negro still within the harbour?

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: Some league from land.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Lest that these English should attempt escape,
Now they are laden fully with our bounties,
Cast thou a watchful eye upon these two.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: I shall.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
I know their loves so fervent and entire,
They will not part asunder, she leave him,
Or he without her make escape to sea.
Then while the one is in sight our hopes are safe.
Be that thy charge.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: I will be an Argus over them.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Unless the King be still in love with Besse,
Repenting him of their late marriage,
It is beyond wonder to calculate these storms.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: How goes the hour?

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: About some four.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
We rose too soon Besse from your nuptial feasts,
Something we tasted made us stomach-sick,
But now we find a more contentful change.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Your sunshine is our day.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Dispose yourselves
All to your free desires; to dancing some,
Others to mount our stately Barbary horse,
So famous through the world for swift career,
Stomach, and fiery pace.
Those that love arms,
Mount for the tilt: this day is yours, to you it is consecrate.
He commits treason in the highest degree,
Whose cloudy brow dares the least tempest show
To cross what we intend: pleasure shall spring
From us to flow on you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Long live the King:

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
To your free pastimes; leave us.
Captain, stay Captain, I read a fortune in thy brow,
More than the slight presage of augury,
Which tells me thou, and only thou art marked
To make me earthly blessed.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: That I can do it?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
It lies in thee to raise thy ruined fortunes
As high as is a Viceroy's, wreathe thy front
Within a circled pyramid of gold,
And to command in all our territories,
Next to our person.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Golden promises.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Our words are acts, our promises are deeds,
We do not feed with air: it lies in thee,
We two may grapple souls, be friends and brothers.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Teach me how.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
I do not find thee coming: in thy looks
I cannot spy that fresh alacrity,
Which with a glad and sprightful forwardness,
Should meet our love half way.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: You wonder me.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
No, thou art dull, or fearful, fare thee well,
Thou hadst a fate lade up to make thee chronicled
In thy own Country, but thou wilt basely lose it,
Even by thine own neglect.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Forespeak me not,
The Sun never met the summer with more joy
Than I would embrace my fortunes; but to you,
Great king, to whom I am so greatly bound,
I would purchased with a danger should fright earth,
Astonish heaven, and make all hell to tremble;
I am of no shrinking temper.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Prove but as wise as thou art bold and valiant,
And gain me wholly to thee, half thou hast already
Purchased by this bold answer; but perform
The rest, and we are all and only thine.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Show me the way to gain this royal purchase,
If I do it not, divide me from your presence,
From your grace, and all those glorious hopes you have proposed
Turn into scorns and scandals.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
I am dull,
And drowsy on the sudden: whilst I sleep,
Captain, read there.

div2.stage: He countersets sleep, and gives him a letter.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
To make Besse mine some secret means devise,To thy own height and heart I will make thee rise.
Is not this ink the blood of Basilisks,
That kills me in the eyes, and blinds me so,
That I can read no further: it was composed
Of Dragons poison, and the gall of Asps,
Of Serpents venom, or of Vipers stings,
It could not read so harsh else: O my fate;
Nothing but this? this? Had a parliament
Of fiends and furies in a synod sat,
And devised, plotted, parleyed, and contrived,
They scarce could second this; This? it is unparalleled:
To strumpet a chaste Lady, injure him
That rates her honour dearer than his life.
To employ a friend in treasons against his friend,
And put that friend to do it: to impose on me
The hateful style and blot of panderism,
That am a Gentleman: nay, worse than this,
Make me in this a traitor to my country,
In giving up their honours: Who but a Moor,
Of all that bears man's shape, likest a devil,
Could have devised this horror? Possible
That he should mark out me? What does my face
Prognosticate, that he should find writ there
An index of such treasons? But beware,
It was his own plot, Aye, and his cunning too:
I will add that to his project: but a Viceroy,
And a kings Minion, titles that will shadow
Ills the most base and branded. Not to do it
May purchase his displeasure, which can be
No less than death or bondage: here is proposed
Honour and peril. But what writes he further;
We are impatient of delays, this night
Let it be done.
I am doubtful of my purpose,
And can resolve of nothing.

div2.stage: Mullisheg starts out of his chaire as from a dream.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
If he fail,
I will have his flesh cut small as winters snow
Or summers atoms.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Ha, was that by us?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Where was I? O, I dreamed upon the sudden,
How fast was I.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
A fair warning it was, have you the cunning
To speak your thoughts in dreams?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Who is in the next room?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: My lord.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
My Captain, was it thou?
Sleep did surprise my senses, worthy friend,
And in my dreams I did remember thee.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: How, me my lord?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Methought I had employed thee in a business,
In which thou wert or fearful, or else false,
At which I was so overcome with rage,
That from my dreams I started.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Seamen say,
When Halcyons sing, look for a storm that day,
There is death in my denial.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Did you read,
That scroll we gave you Captain, there is wrapped up
A thousand honours for thee, and more gold
Than shouldst thou live a double Nestors age,
Thou couldst find ways to lavish.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Add to your work a business of more danger,
That I may think me worthy, otherwise
This sleight employment will but prize me low
And of desertless merit.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Thinkst thou Captain
It may be easily compassed?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Dare you trust me?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I dare.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Then know, besides to dare and can,
I will, though work beyond the power of man,
I will set my brains in action.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Noble friend,
Above thy thoughts our honours shall extend.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I am not to be shaken.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Where be our Eunuchs?
We will crown our hopes and wishes with more pomp
And sumptuous cost, than Priam did his sons,
That night he bosomed Helen; she is as fair,
And we will command our pomp to be as rare.
We will have torches shall exceed the stars
In number and in brightness: we will have
Rare change of music shrill and high,
That shall exceed the spheres in harmony.
The jewels of her habit shall reflect,
To daze all eyes that shall behold her state.
Our treasure shall like to a torrent rush
Streams of rewards, richer than Tagus sands,
To make these English strangers swim in gold.
In wild Moriscos we will lead the bride:
And when with full satieties of pleasures
We are dull and satiate, at her radiant eyes
Kindle fresh appetite, since they aspire,
To exceed in brightness the high orbs of fire.
Make this Night mine, as we are King of Fesse,
Thou art Viceroy, Captain.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Make my estate much less,
And my attempts more honourable: honour and virtue,
To me seem things in opposition:
Nor can we with small danger catch at one,
But we must lose the other. O my brain,
In what a labyrinth art thou? Say I could
Be false, as he would make me; what device?
What plot? what train have I to compass it?
Or with what face can I solicit her,
In treason towards my friend?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
I am to solicit Spencer
To lie with the Moors Queen; a business, Besse
Will hardly thank me for: but howsoever
I have undertaken it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Impossibilities all; the more I wade,
The more I drown in weakness.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Captain.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
O Lieutenant,
Never was man perplexed thus.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
What, as you?
Had you but my disturbance in your brain,
It would tax a Stoics wit, or Oedipus.
Why Captain, a whole school of Sophisters
Could not unriddle me.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I would we might change business.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I would give boot so to be rid of mine.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Shall we be free and open breasted?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
As thus;
Tell me thy grievances, and unto thee
I will unveil my bosom: both disclosed
I will beg in mine thy counsel and assistance,
Thy cause shall mine command.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: A heart, a hand.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I am to woo fair Besse to lie with Mullisheg.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: And I woo Spencer to embrace the Queen.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: It is more than possible, it is absolutely past.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: There is not a hair to chose, canst counsel me?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Can you advise me?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I am past my wits.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: And I beyond all sense.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Wouldst thou do it, here lay the way plain before
thee.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
What, for gold
Betray my friend and country, would you Captain?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
What and wear a sword
To guard my honour and a Christians faith,
I would flesh it here first.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Nobly resolved.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
We are not safe Lieutenant, Moors are treacherous.
Nay come, thy counsel,
Fesse hath proffered me
The honour of a Viceroy; and withal,
If I should fail performance, cunningly
Hath threatened me with death.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
You still propose
The danger, but you show no way to clear them.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Brain, let me waken thee, 'sfoot hast thou no
project? dost thou partake my dullness?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: The more I strive, the more I am entangled.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And I too. Not yet?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Nor yet, nor ever.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: It was coming here, now again it is vanished.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Call it back again for heavens sake.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Again.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Thanks heaven.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And now again it is gone.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Can you not catch fast hold on it?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Give me way,
Let us walk Lieutenant: Could a man propose
A stratagem to gull this lustful Moor,
To supply him, and then to satiate her?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Next, out of all these dangers secure us,
And keep our treasure safe.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: It were excellent.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: But how shall this be done?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Why Captain, know not you?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Thinkst thou it in the power of man to work it?
Yet come, I will try, I owe my fate a death,
Be swayed by me in all things.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Noble Captain, I do not wish to outlive thee.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p:
The King was wondrous pleasant: O my Besse,
How much am I indebted to his highness,
Only for gracing thee.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Could my Spencer
Think that a barbarous Moor could be so trained
In human virtues?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Fie upon it: I am so tired with dancing with
these same black she-chimney-sweepers, that I can scarce
set the best leg forward, they have so tired me with their
Moriscoes, and I have so tickled them with our Country
dances, Sellengers round, and Tom Tiler: we have so fiddled
it.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Sirrah, what news will you tell to your friends
when you return into England.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Brave news, which though I can neither write
nor read, yet I have committed them to my tables and
the rest of my memory.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Let us hear some of your novelties.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
First and foremost I have observed the wisdom
of these Moors, for some two days since being invited
to one of the chief Bashaws to dinner, after meat, sitting
by a huge fire, and feeling his shins to burn, I requested
him to pull back his chair, but he very understandingly
sent for three or four Masons and removed the chimney:
the same Morian entreated me to lie with him, and I according
to the state of my travels, willing to have a candle
burning by, but he by no means would grant it; I
asked him why? No, says he, we will put out the light
that the fleas may not know where to find us.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
No storm at sea could be so tyrannous,
Nor half the affright bear in his forehead bare,
As I spy in that look.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Let not your looks presage more terrors than
Your tongues can speak; out with it at once Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Captain speak.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: We are all lost.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: All shipwrecked.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Are we ashore, and shall we be cast away?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Great Mullisheg is royal.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: False to you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Gracious and kind.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Disloyal to us all.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Wrap me not in these wonders worthy friend,
The very doubt of what the danger is,
Is more than danger can be.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Be it death,
So we may dye together: here is a heart
Fear never could affright.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: The king still loves your Besse.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: The Queen your Spencer.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: This night he must enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: And she him.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
A thousand deaths are in that word contrived.
I will make my passage through the blood of kings,
Rather than suffer this.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I through hell,
Or were there place more dangerous.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Else all die.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Die, 'sfoot this is worse than being made an
Eunuch as I was.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: We have yet life, and therefore cherish hope.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
All hopes are banished in the deep abyss
Of our perplexed thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: All things run retrograde.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Why Captain? why Lieutenant? had you the skill
To bring my ship thus far, to wrack her here?
Past you the Ocean, to perish in the harbour?
Thou, Tom Goodlack
Wert ever true and just to my designs,
And canst thou fail me now?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: I study for you.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Hast thou brought me but to see my Spencers shadow,
And not enjoy the substance: for what more
Have I yet had from him, than from his picture,
That once hung in my Chamber. Gentlemen, amongst you all
Rescue an innocent maid from violence:
Or do but say it cannot be prevented.
I begin, he that best loves me follow.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What means Besse?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
If it could be fashioned to my thoughts,
And have success, it were brave.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What, noble friend?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: To thrive but as we purpose.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Have you way?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
It is but a desperate course; and if it fail
The worst can be but death: and I, even I,
That laid the plot, will teach them how to dye.
I will lead them on.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: If thou hast any project.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Joy or comfort.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: And if not comfort, counsel.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Say it thrive?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What Captain? what?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
You will rip it from the womb
Ere it be fully hatched now:
If it prosper but to my desire
And wishes, it were admirable.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
No longer hold us in suspense, good Captain.
But free us from these fears.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
You noble friend,
This night cast gracious eyes upon the Queen:

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: And prove to me disloyal?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Still you cross me,
And make the birth abortive. You fair Besse,
With amorous favours entertain the King.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: And yield herself to his intemperate lust?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
You still prevent me; either give me way
To show you light unto your liberties,
Or still remain in darkness.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Hear him out.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
You sooth the Queen,
I will flatter with the King,
Let us promise fair on both sides; say, it is done
All to their own desires.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: The event of this?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
A happy freedom, with a safe escape
Unto our ship this night.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: O, could this be.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Fortune assists the valiant and the bold,
We will bid fare for it. I had forgot myself,
Where is Clem?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Noble Captain.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Post to the ship, bid Forset man the long Boat
With ten good Musketeers, and at a watchword,
If we can free our passage, take us in.
Nay, make haste, one minute's stay is death.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I am gone in a twinkling.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
To compass the Kings signet; then to command
Our passage, scape the gates and watches too:
For that I have brain. The King is upon his entrance;
Hours waste, revels come on, a thousand projects
Of death, hopes, and fears, are warring
In my bosom, and at once.
Eye you the Queen, and humour you the King;
Let no distaste nor discontented brow
Appear in you: their lust I will make the ground,
To set all free, or keep your honour sound.
Disperse, the King is on coming.

div2.stage: Enter Mullisheg, Tota, Ioffer, and Alcade.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
We consecrate this evening, beauteous Bride,
To the honour of your nuptials. - Is all done?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Done.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Is he ours?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Yours.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: And we ever thine.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Aye, and so cast, that she shall grasp you freely;
And think she hugs her Spencer.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
And when he bosoms you, thinks he enfolds
His lovely Besse.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Thou makest a Queen thy servant.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Your highness Signet to command our passage
from chamber to chamber.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: It is there.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: The word.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: It is Mullisheg.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: This must bring us safe aboard.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
We keep the Bride
Too long from rest now, she is free for bed.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Please her to accept it,
In honour of her beauty, this night I will do her any service.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Mighty princess,
Excuse my breeding from such arrogance,
And overbold presumption, you nor yours
Can owe me any duty: it is besides
The fashion of our country, not to trust
The secrets of a nuptial night like this,
To the eyes of any stranger.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: At your pleasure,

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
With our first nights unlacing, mighty Queen,
We dare not trust our husbands, it is a modesty
Our English maids profess.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Keep your own customs as you shall think best,
So for this night we leave you to your rest.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Remember.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: It is writ here.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Captain,

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
I am fast,
Now is my task in labour, and is plunged
In thousand throes of childbirth, dangerous it is
To deal where kings affairs are questioned,
Or may be parleyed. But what is he so base,
That would not all his utmost powers extend,
For freedom of his country and his friend.
When all the Court is silent, sunk in dreams,
Then must my spirits awake. By this the King
Has taken his leave of bride and bridegroom too:
And the amorous Queen longs for some happy news
From Ruffman, as great Fesse expects from us.
My friend and Besse wrapped in a thousand fears,
To find my plot in action: and it now
Must take new life: auspicious fate thy aid,
To guard the honour of this English maid.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Tread soft, good Madam.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Is this the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
I will bring him instantly.
He thinks this bed provided for his Besse,
And that she lodges here, while she poor soul
Embraceth naught but air.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Thou makest a Queen thy servant.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Beware, be not too loud lest that your tongue
Betrays you.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Mute as night,
As silent and as secret. Wrongs should be
Paid with wrongs, for so indeed it is meet,
My just revenge, though secret yet it is sweet.
Haste time, and hast our bounty.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Queen I shall.
So now were we all safe and in our Negro shipped,
Mightst thou lie there till dooms day, lustful Queen.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
My lord the custom is in England still
For maids to go to bed before their husbands,
It saves their cheek from many a modest blush.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: And in the dark.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: We use it for the most part.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Soft may their bones lie in their beds of ashes
That brought this custom into England first.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: This the place where Besse expects her Spencer.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Thou Viceroy of Argiers, for Captain, that
Is now thy title: thou hast won a King,
To be thy breast companion.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Not too loud.
Why enters not your highness? you are safe.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
With as much joy as to our prophets rest.
But what thinks Spencer of this?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
I have shifted in her place
A certain Moor, whom I have hired for money,
Which (poor soul) he entertains for Besse.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: My excellent friend.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Beware of conference, lest your tongue reveals
What this safe darkness hides.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
I am all silent.
O, thou contentful night, into thy arms,
Of all that ever I tasted, sweetest and best,
I throw me, more for pleasure than for rest.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
One fury clasp another, and there beget
Young devils between you: so fair Besse be safe.
I have here the kings signet, this will yield us
Way through the court and city, Besse being masked,
How can she be descried, when none suspect,
Our flight this day not dreamed on: now to execute
What was before purposed, which if it speed,
I will say the heavens have in our fates agreed.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: How goes the night?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: It is some two hours from day.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Yet no news from the Captain.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
I have done a Midwives part, I have brought the
Queen to bed, I could do no more.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: The Captain is come.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Thy news.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
All safe, faith wench, I have put them to it for
a single combat, I have left them at it.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: King and Queen.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Now for us.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Aye, there is all the danger, there is one Bashaw
Whose eyes is fixed on Spencer, and he now
Walks even before our lodging.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Then what is past,
Is all yet to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
He and I
May freely pass the Court: and you fair Besse,
I would disguise: but then for Spencer?

sp.speaker: Besse
sp.p:
Why that is the main of all: all without his freedom
That we can aim at is, nothing.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
It shall be thus, which alter none that loves me.
With this signet you three shall pass to the ship
Whilst I am in sight she will not be suspected:
My escape, leave to my own fair fortunes.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: How that?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Through twenty Bashaws I will hew my way,
But I will see thee ere morning.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Thinkst thou Spencer
That I will leave thee? thinkst thou that I can?
Thou mayst as well part body from the soul,
As part us now: It is our wedding night,
Wouldst now divide us?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Yield to times necessities, and to our strict disasters.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Words are vain,
We now must cleave to action: our stay is death,
And if we be not quick in expedition,
We all perish.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Besse, be swayed.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
To go to sea without thee,
And leave thee subject unto a tyrants cruelty?
I will dye a thousand deaths first.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
First save one,
And by degrees the rest. When thou hast past
The perils of this night, I am half safe,
But whilst thou art still environed, more than better
Half of my part is endangered.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Talk yourselves
To your deaths, do: will you venture forth?
Leave me to the Bashaw.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or me, I will buffet with him for my passage.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Neither, in what I purpose I am constant.
Conduct her safe; the advantage of the night
I will take for my escape: and my sweet Besse,
If in the morning I behold thee not
Safe within my Negro, be assured
I am dead. Nay, now delays are vain.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Sir, did you love
Me, you would not stay behind me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I will have it so.
Gentlemen, be chary of this jewel
That throws herself into the arms of night,
Under your conduct. If I live, my Besse,
Tomorrow I will not fail thee.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
And if thou diest tomorrow, be assured
Tomorrow I will be with thee.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Shall thy love
Betray us all to death.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Well, I will go,
But if thou dost miscarry, think the Ocean
To be my Bride-bed.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Heaven for us,
That power that hath preserved us hitherto,
Will not let us sink now. And, brave gentlemen,
Of the Moors bounty bear not anything
Unto our ship, lest they report of us,
We fled by night and robbed them.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Nobly resolved.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Now embrace and part; and my sweet Besse,
This be thy comfort gainst all future fears,
To meet in mirth that now divide in tears:
Farewell Besse, I will back into my chamber.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Can I part with life
In more distracted horror?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
You spoil all.
That we before have plotted.
Will you mask yourself, and to the Porter first.
Ho, Porter.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: One from the King.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: How shall I know that?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
This token be your warrant, behold his signet.
That is not enough, the Word.

sp.speaker: Port.
Alcad.
sp.p:
I much suspect,
These English amongst themselves are treacherous:
I have observed, the king had conference with the Captain:
many whisperings and passages I have observed,
but that which makes me most suspect is, because the king
hath removed his lodging, and it may be to prostitute the
English Maid: Ha, suspect said I; nay, examine things
exactly, and it must needs be so, the king is wondrous
bountiful, and what is it gold cannot. Troth I could even
pity the poor forlorn Englishman, who this night must
be forced lie alone, and have the king taste to him.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Sure this Moore hath been made private to the
Kings intents, which if I find, I will make him the instrument
for me to pass the Court gates. This man, whose
office was to keep me, shall be the only means to free me.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
On his marriage night, and up at this hour?
nay, if I once suspect, it is as firm as if it were confirmed
by Alkaron, or Mahomet himself had sworn it: I will sport
myself with his distaste and sorrow.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Thus abused.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
What up so late and on your bridal night
When you should lie lulled in the fast embrace
Of your fair Mistress. I hope I have given it him soundly.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
is possible,
To lodge my bride in one place, and dispose me
To a wrong chamber: she not once send to me,
That I might know to find her.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
Excellent.
Nay, if I once suspect, it never fails.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I will not take it
At the hands of an Empress, much less at hers.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
Why, what is the business, Sir? O, I guess
the cause of your grief.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: And Sir, you may, but I will be revenged.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: Troth and I would.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I will bosom somebody,
Be it the commonest Courtesan in Fesse,
If not for love, to vex her.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: Can you do less?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: To leave me the first night.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: O, it was a sign she never dearly loved you.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: I perceive Bashaw Alcade you understand my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: In part, though not in whole.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Your word is warrant, pass me the court gate,
I will to some loose Bordello, and tell her when I have done.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: Were it my cause, I would do this, and more.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Make me wait thus!

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: O Sir, it is insufferable.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Troth I dally my revenge too long, what ho,

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: How now, who calls?

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: Here is Bashaw Alcade, turn the key.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: His name commands my gate, pass freely.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Sir, I am bound to you,
To take this wrong I should be held no man.
Now to the watch, scape there as I can.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, so long as she sleeps in the arms of Fesse,
let him pack where he pleases: Porter, now he is without,
let him command his entrance no more, neither for reward
nor entreaty, till day breaks.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Sir, he shall not.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
It is well we are so rid of him: Mullisheg will
give me great thanks for this.
I will to his chamber, there attend without,
Till he shall waken from his drowsy rest,
And then acquaint him with this fortunate jest.

div2.stage: Enter Ioffer, Lieutenant, Spencer prisoner and wounded.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
Sir, though we wonder at your noble deeds,
Yet I must do the office of a subject,
And take you prisoner: by that noble blood
That runs in these my veins, when I behold
The slaughter you have made, which wonders me,
I wish you had escaped, and not been made captive
To him, who though he may admire and love you,
Yet cannot help you.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Your style is like your birth, for you are Ioffer,
Chief Bashaw to the king, and him I know
Lord of most noble thoughts. Speak, what is my danger?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
Know Sir, a double forfeit of your life:
Your outrage first is death, being in the night,
And against the watch; but those that you have slain
In this fierce conflict, brings them without all bounds
Of pardon.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: I was born to it, and I embrace my fortune.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
Sir, now I know you
To be that brave and worthy Englishman,
So highly graced in court, which more amazeth me
That you should thus requite him with the slaughter
Of his loved subjects.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I entreat you Sir,
As you are noble question me no further,
I have many private thoughts that trouble me,
And not the fear of death.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
We know your name, and now have proved your courage,
Both these moves us to give you as easy bondage as our loyalty
To the king can suffer, you are free
From irons.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: When this news shall come to her,

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
Lieutenant, lead the watch some distance off,
Bid them remove these bodies lately slain,
I must have private conference with this prisoner,
Leave him to my charge.
Sir think me though a Moore,
A nation strange unto you Christians,
Yet that I can be noble: but in you
I have observed strange contrarieties,
Which I would be resolved in.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Speak your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
When I conferred the nobleness of your blood,
With this your present passion, I much muse,
Why either such a small effuse of blood,
These your sleight wounds, or the pale fear of death,
Should have the power to force a tear from such
A noble eye.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Why thinkst thou Bashaw
That wounds, blood, or death
Could force a tear from me, thou noblest of thy nation,
Do not so far misprize me: I tell thee Bashaw,
The rack, strappado, or the scalding oil,
The burning pincers, or the boiling lead,
The stakes, the pikes, the cauldron, or the wheel,
Were all these tortures to be felt an once,
Could not draw water hence.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Whence comes it then?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
From that whose pains as far surmounts all those
As whips of furies do the Ladies fans,
Made of the plumes of the Ostrich: this like the Sun,
Extracts the dew from my declining soul,
And swims mine eyes in moist effeminacy.
O Besse, Besse, Besse, Besse.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
Dead pity you have wakened in my bosom,
And made me with you like compassionate.
Freely relate your sorrows.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Sir, I shall:
If you have ever loved, or such a maid,
So fair, so constant, and so chaste as mine,
And should fortune to lamentable fortune,
Betray her to a black abortive fate,
How would it wring you? Or if you had a heart,
Made of that metal that we white men have,
How would it melt in you?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Sir, you confound me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I will be brief; the travels of my Besse,
To find me out, you have partook at full,
In presence of the King, these I omit.
Now when we came to sum up all our joy,
And this night were entering to our hoped bliss,
The king, O most unworthy of that name,
He quite fell off from goodness.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Who Mullisheg?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
His lust outweighed his honour: and as if his soul
Were blacker than his face, he laid plots
To take this sweet night from me: but prevented,
I have conveyed my beauteous bride aboard,
My Captain and Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Are they escaped?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Safe to my Negro. Thus far fortune led me
Through many dangers till I past this bridge,
The last of all your watches. And muse not
Bashaw, that I thus single durst oppose myself,
I wore my Mistress here, and she, not I,
Made me midway a conqueror.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
She being at sea,
And safe, why should your own fates trouble you?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Renowned Moor, there is your greatest error;
When, we parted, I swore by the honour of a Gentleman,
And as I ever was her constant friend,
If I survived, to visit her aboard
By such an hour: but if I fail, that she
Should think me dead: now, if I break one minute,
She leaps into the sea: it is this, great Bashaw,
That from a soldiers eyes draws pearly tears:
For my own person I despise all fears.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
You have deeply touched me: and to let you know
All moral virtues are not solely grounded
In the hearts of Christians, go and pass free;
Keep your appointed hour, preserve her life:
I will conduct you past all danger: but withal
Remember my head is left to answer it.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Is honour fled from Christians unto Moors,
That I may say in Barbary I found
This rare black Swan.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
And when you are at sea,
The wind no question may blow fair, your anchors
They are soon weighed, and you have sea-room free
To pass unto your country: it is but my life,
And I shall think it nobly spent to save you,
Her, and your train from many sad disasters.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Sir, I thank you,
Appoint me a fixed hour, if I return not,
May I be held a scorn to Christendom,
And recreant to my country.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: By three tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Bind me by some oath.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Only your hand and word.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Which if I break.
What my heart thinks, my tongue forbears to speak.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: I will bear you past all watches.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Through satiate with the pleasures of this night,
The morning calls me from the sweet embraces
Of the fair English Damsel.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
The English stranger
Is stolen from forth mine arms. I am at full revenged:
Were I again to match, I would marry one
Of this brave nation, if a Gentleman,
Before the greatest Monarch of the world,
They are such sweet and loving bedfellows.
Now to my chamber, darkness guide my way,
Lest what none yet suspect, the night betray.
Let all like me wronged in their nuptial bed,
Not aim at the heart, but rather strike at the head.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Venetian Ladies, nor the Persian Girls,
The French, the Spanish, nor the Turkish Dames,
Ethiope nor Greece can kiss with half that art
These English can, nor entertain their friends
With the tenth part of that ample willingness
Within their arms.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: Your highness called?

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
To tell thee that none shall partake but thou.
O, I have had the sweetest nights content
That ever king enjoyed.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: With the fair English bride.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Nor envy if I raise the Captain for it,
For he shall mount.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
And he deserves it: but to me you owe
Part of that honour, I had a hand in it too,
Although perhaps you thought me ignorant
In what is past.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
Hadst thou no more
Than half a finger in this nights content,
It shall not be forgot, but thou as he
Shalt be raised one step higher.

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p:
Observing what had past, I spied the bridegroom.
As still mine eyes were fixed on him, up and late,
Then by a trick, a pretty sleight, a fine fetch of mine own,
I past him forth the gates, and gave command,
He should not have his entrance back again,
Neither for reward nor entreaties, till day broke.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Your aim in that?

sp.speaker: Alc.
sp.p:
For fear lest he by some suspicious jealousy
Should have disturbed your rest.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Thy providence
Shall not die unrewarded: shift him hence,
And with his will too, this makes thee
Of our counsel.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
It is an honour
My wisdom have long aimed at, and I hope
Now shall receive his merit.

sp.speaker: Negr.
sp.p:
Pardon great king that I thus rudely press
Into your private bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Speak, thy news.

sp.speaker: Negr.
sp.p:
The English Captain, with the lovely Bride,
With her Lieutenant hath secretly this night,
With your highness signet and the word past the Court-gates,
past all the watches, and got aboard their Negro, and
I was sent to know your highness pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Ha, this night? Alcade, seek, search,
I left her sleeping in our royal bed.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: I shall my lord, I half suspect.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: But was not Spencer with them?

sp.speaker: Negr.
sp.p:
Only they three: and we, by virtue of your
highness signet, past them the court-gates without
trouble.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
We are amazed:
Alcade, whom findest thou there?

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
Nothing, my lord, but empty sheets,
A bed new tossed; but neither English Lady, nor
any Lady else.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p:
We stand astonished,
Not knowing what to answer.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Pardon great king if I relate the news
That will offend you highly.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
That the English Captain, Lady, and Lieutenant
are escaped.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: But that is not all.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Can there be worse behind?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Yes, if the loss of your dear subjects lives
Be worse than their escape: Spencer, without
The signet or the word, being left behind.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
You called the porter up
And let him after.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p: Pardon great King.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Was this your trick, your sleight, your stratagem?
As we are king of Fesse, thy life shall pay
The forfeit, thine own tongue shall sentence thee.
But to the rest.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
Then past he to the bridge,
Where stood armed men, in number forty:
Maugre all their strength, with his good sword
He would have made through all:
And in this fierce conflict, six, to the maze
Of all the rest, were slain: nor would he yield,
Till suddenly we raised a loud alarm,
At which the Captain of the watch came down,
And so there surprised him.

sp.speaker: Mul.
sp.p: Is he prisoner then?

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
In custody of the great Bashaw Ioffer,
With whom we left him.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Command our Bashaw
To bring him clogged in irons. These English Pirates
Have robbed us of much treasure: and for that
His traitorous life shall answer. But for thee, traitor,
That hadst a hand in his escape,
Thou shalt be sure to pay for it.

sp.speaker: Alcad.
sp.p:
Alas, my lord,
What I did was merely ignorance.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Nay bribes,
And I shall find it so: bear him to guard.
What dissolute strumpet did that traitorous Captain
Send to our sheets; but all our injuries,
Upon that English prisoner we will revenge,
As we in state and fortune hope to rise,
A never heard of death that traitor dies.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
No news from Forset yet that waits for Spencer,
The long boat has not returned?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Not yet?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Clem. to the main top Clem, and give us notice
if thou seest any (like them) make from the shore; the day
is broke already.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
With all my heart, so you will give me warning
before the Gunner shoots, lest I tumble down again, and
put my neck a second time in danger.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Prithee be gon, let us have no jesting now.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Then I will to the main top in earnest.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: How fares it with you Besse?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Like a heartless creature, a body without motion.
How can I chose when I am come to sea,
And left my heart ashore? What, no news yet?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
I prithee Ruffman step into my Cabin, and bring
me here my hour glass.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: That I shall.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: To what end would you use it?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Shall I tell thee Captain,
I would know how long I have to live:
That glass once turned, the sandy hour quite run,
I know my Spencer is dead, and my life is done.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Your glass.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Gramercy good Lieutenant:
It is better than a gaudy looking glass,
To deck our faces in; that shows our pride,
But this our ends those glasses seek to hide.
Have you been all at prayers?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We have.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I thank you
Gentlemen, never more need: and you would say
As I do, did you but know how near our ends some are.
Dost thou not think, Captain, my Spencer is slain?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Yet hope the best.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
This is the hour he promised: Captain, look,
For I have not the heart, and truly tell me
How far it is spent
Some fifteen minutes.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Alas, no more; I prithee take it away,
Even just so many have I left to pray,
And then to break my heart strings: None that loves me
Speak one word to me of him, or anything:
If in your secret cabins you will bestow
Of him and me some tears and hearty prayers,
We, if we live shall thank you. Good Gentlemen
Engage me so far to you.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: News, news, news.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Ha, good or bad.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Excellent, most excellent, nay, super excellent,
Forset and all his companions are rowing hither like mad
men; and there is one that sits in the stern and does not
row at all, and that is, let me see who is it? I am sure it is
he, noble Spencer.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Spencer?
Heart, let me keep thee; thou wast up to heaven
Half way in rapture. Art thou sure?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I think you will make a man swear his heart out.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Teach me but how
I shall receive him when he comes aboard;
How shall I bear me, Captain, that my joy
Do not transcend my soul out of this earth,
Into the air with passionate ecstasy:

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Now farewell Barbary, king Mullisheg,
We have sea room, and wind at will, not ten
Of thy best Galleys armed with Moors,
Can fetch us back.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: For England Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
O, where is the Gunner:
See all the ordnance be straight discharged
For joy my Spencer lives; let us mist ourselves
In a thick cloud of smoke, and speak our joys
Unto the highest heavens in fire, and thunder.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: To make the Queen vex and torment herself.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
To make the King tear his contorted locks,
Curled like the knots of furies: O this music
Doth please me better than the effeminate strings,
Tuned to their wild Moriscos: dance my soul,
And caper in my bosom, joyful heart,
That I have here my Spencer.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Come, weigh Anchor,
Hoist sail, we have a fair and gentle gale
To bear us to our country.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Captain, stay.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I did not hear my Spencer speak till now,
Nor would my sudden joy give me that judgment
To spy that sadness in thee I now see;
Good, what is the cause, canst thou conceal it from me?
What, from thy Besse? Whence came that sigh?
You will not tell me; no, do not:
I am not worthy to partake your thoughts.
Do you repent you that you see us safe
Embarked for England to enjoy me there:
Is there some other whom you better love?
Let me but know her, and for your sweet sake
I will serve her too: come, I will know the cause.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Know all in one:
Now I have seen you, I must leave you Besse.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Leave me? O, fatal.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Speak, my Besse, it is thy Spencer tells thee.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
That he will leave me: if the same tongue
That wounded me, gives me no present cure,
It will again entrance me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Arm yourself,
It must be spoke again, for I must leave you.
My honour, faith, and country are engaged,
The reputation of a Christian is pawned;
And all that wear that sacred livery,
Shall in my breach be scandaled. Moors will say,
We boast of faith, none does good works but they.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I am nor sleep nor waking, but my senses
All in a confused slumber.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
Spenc.
sp.p:
I shall;
I made my way through slaughter; but at length
The watch came down and took me prisoner
Unto a noble Bashaw: for my valour,
It pleased him to admire me: but when sorrow
To disappoint my Besse, struck me in passion,
He urged me freely to relate my griefs,
Which took in him such deep impression,
That on my word and promise to return
By such an hour, he left himself in hostage,
To give me my desires.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
It was nobly done.
But what is the lives of twenty thousand Moors,
To one that is a Christian?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
We have liberty, and free way to our country,
Shall not we take the advantage that the heavens
Have lent us: but now, as if we scorned
Their gracious bounty, give up ourselves
To voluntary bondage.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Prize you my love no better, than to rate it
Beneath the friendship of a barbarous Moor?
Can you, to save him, leave me to my death? Is this
The just reward of all my travels?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I prize my honour, and a Christians faith,
Above what earth can yield: shall Fesse report,
Unto our country's shame, and to the scandal
Of our religion, that a barbarous Moor
Can exceed us in nobleness? no, I will die
A hundred thousand deaths first.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
O, my fate, was ever maid thus crossed,
That have so oft been brought to see my bliss,
And never taste it? to meet my Spencer living after death,
To join with him in marriage, not enjoy him?
To have him here free from the barbarous Moors,
And now to lose him? being so oft raised
Unto the height of all felicity
To make my ruin greater. If you needs
Will hazard your own person, make me partner
In this thy present danger; take me with thee.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Not for the world, no living soul shall bleed
One drop for me.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Canst thou be so unkind? then false man know,
That thou hast taught me harshness. I without
Thee came to Momarah, and to my country back,
I will return without thee: I am here
In mine own vessel, mine own train about me:
And since thou wilt forsake me, to embrace
The Queen of Moors: though coining strange excuse.
Even at thy pleasure be it, my way is into my country,
Farewell, I will not shed one tear more.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
My partings death,
But honour wakens me, the hour draws nigh,
And if I fail one minute, he must die.
The long boat now. Farewell Besse.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Why, farewell
Spencer, I always loved thee but too well,
Captain, thine ear,
This I have vowed, and this you all shall swear.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Produce your prisoner, Bashaw.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
Mighty King,
Had you beheld his prowess, and withal,
But seen his passions, you would then like me,
Have pitied his disasters.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
We know no pity for an injury
Of that high nature, more than our revenge,
We have vowed his death, and he shall therefore die.
Go, bring him forth.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Spare me, my lord; but some few hours, I shall.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: The least delay is death.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: Then know, my lord, he was my prisoner.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: How, was? and is not?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: By promise.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: Not in gyves.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p: He has gyved to me by faith, but else at liberty.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
I pray unriddle us, and teach us that
Which we desire to know, where is the English prisoner?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
I presumed, my lord,
Such noble valour could not be lodged alone,
Without some other virtues, faith and honour,
Therefore I gave him freedom to his ship,
Only upon his promise to return;
Now if there be such nobleness in a Christian,
Which being a Moor, I have expressed to him,
He will not see me perish.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Foolish Bashaw
To jest away thy head: you are all conspirators
Against our person: and you all shall die.
Why? canst thou think a stranger so remote,
Both in country and religion, being embarked
At sea, and under sail, free from our bands
In the arms of his fair bride,
His Captain and his sailors all aboard,
Sea room and wind at will, and will return
To expose all these to voluntary dangers,
For a bare verbal promise?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
If he comes nor,
Be this mine honour, King, that though I bleed,
A Moor a Christian thus far did exceed.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
The hour is past,
The Christian hath broke faith.
Off with his head.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Yet come at last.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Is it possible?
Can England so far distant harbour such noble virtues?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
I beshrew you, Sir,
You come unto your death, and you have taken
Much honour from me, and engrossed it all
To your own fame; it would have lived longer by me,
Than any monument can last, to have lost
My life for such a noble stranger,
Whose virtue even in this last act appears,
I wish this blood, which now are friendly tears.
You are come unto your death.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Why, it was my purpose;
And by that death, to make my honour shine.
Great Mullisheg, cherish this noble Moor,
Whom all thy confines cannot parallel
For virtue and true nobleness. Ere my ship
Should with such black dishonour bear me safe
Into my country by thy Bashaws death,
I would have bent my ordnance against her keel,
And sunk her in the harbour.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Thou hast slain
Six of our subjects.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
O, had you seen
But with what eminent valour.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Naught that is ill
Can be well done: then Bashaw, speak no more,
His life is merely forfeit, and he shall pay it.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I am proud, Fesse, that I now owe thee nothing,
But have in me ability to pay.
If it be forfeit, take it, lay all on me,
I will pay the debt, then set the Bashaw free.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Besides, misprising all our gracious favours,
To violate our laws, infringe our peace,
Disturb our watch by night, and now perhaps
Having robbed us of much treasure, stolen to sea.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
In that thou art not royal, Mullisheg.
Of all thy gold and jewels lately given us,
There is not a doit embarked,
For finding thee dishonourably unkind,
Scorning thy gold, we left it all behind.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
If private men be lords of such brave spirits,
How royal should their Princes be!

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Englishman,
There is but one way for thee to save thy life,
From eminent death.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Well, propose it.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Instantly
Send to thy Negro, and surrender up
Thy Captain and thy fair Bride; otherwise,
By all the holy rights of our great Prophet,
Thou shalt not live an hour.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Alas, good King,
I pity and despise thy tyranny:
Not live an hour? And when my head is off,
What canst thou do then? Call'st thou that revenge,
To ease me of a thousand turbulent griefs,
And throw my soul in glory for my honour.
Why, thou strivest to make me happy but for her;
Wert thou the King of all the kings on earth.
Couldst thou lay all their sceptres, robes, and crowns,
Here at my feet, and hadst power to install me
Emperor of the universal Empery,
Rather than yield my basest ship-boy up,
To become thy slave; much less betray my Bride
To thee and to thy brutish lust, know king
Of Fesse, I would die a hundred thousand deaths first.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p: I will try your patience: Off with his head.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Here is more work, stay.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
What make you here?
You wrong me above injury.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
If you love blood,
That river spare, and for him take a flood,
Be but so gracious as save him alone,
And great King see I bring thee three for one:
Spare him, thou shalt have more,
The lives of all my train, what sayst thou to it?
And with their lives my ship and all to boot.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I could be angry with you above measure,
In your four deaths I die, that had before
Tasted but one.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Captain, art thou there? how ever these fare,
Thou shalt be sure to pay for it.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
It is my least care,
What is done is mine, I here confess it,
Then seize my life in ransom of the rest.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
Lieutenant, you are a base villain,
What groom betrayed you to our sheets?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Please keep your tongue, I did you no dishonour.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: Whom did you bring to our free embraces?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: It was the King, conceal what is past.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p: How ever my mind, then yet my body is chaste.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Make use of it.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Dismiss, great King, these to their ship again,
My life is solely forfeit, take but that,
I shall report thee merciful.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
It were no justice, King, to forfeit his,
And to spare mine, I am as deep as he,
Since what my Spencer did was all for me.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Great King, if any faulted, then it was I,
I led them on, and therefore first should die.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I am as deep as any.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
O, had my head
Excused all these, I had been nobly dead.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Why pause you king? Is it by our noble virtues,
That you have lost the use of speech? or can you think
That Spencer dead, you might inherit me.
No, first with Roman Portia I would eat fire,
Or with Lucretia character thy lust
Betwixt these two breasts. Stood I engaged to death.
I would scorn for life to bend a servile knee:
But it is for thee, my Spencer, what was his fault?
It was but to save his own, rescue his dear Bride
From adulterate sheets, and must he die for this?

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Shall lust in me have chief predominance?
And virtuous deeds, for which in Fesse
I have been long renowned, be quite exiled?
Shall Christians have the honour
To be sole heirs of goodness, and we Moors,
Barbarous and bloody. Captain, resolve me,
What common Courtesan didst thou convey
Into our royal bed.

sp.speaker: Tot.
sp.p:
I can excuse him, pardon me great King,
I having private notice of your plots,
Wrought him unto my purpose, and it was I
lodged in your arms that night.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
These English ever in all things honourable,
Nor can we tax their ways in anything,
Unless we blame their virtues. English maid,
We give thee once more back unto thy husband,
Whom likewise freely we receive to grace:
And as amends for our pretended wrongs,
With her we will tender such an ample dower,
As shall renown our bounty: but we fear
We cannot recompense the injurious loss,
Of your last nights expectations.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
It is full amends,
Where but the least part of your grace extends.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Captain, we prize thy virtues to thy friends,
Thy faith to us, and zeal unto our Queen.
And Bashaw, for thy nobleness to a Gentleman
Of such approved valour and renown,
We here create thee Viceroy of Argiers,
And do esteem thee next our Queen in grace.
You have quenched in me all lust, by which shall grow,
Virtues which Fesse, and all the world shall know.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
We shall report your bounties, and your royalties
Shall fly through all the parts of Christendom.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Whilst Besse has gold, which is the meed of bays,
She will make our English Poets tune thy praise.
And now my Spencer, after all our troubles,
Crosses and threatenings of the seas rough brow,
I never could say thou wert mine own till now.

sp.speaker: Mull.
sp.p:
Call this your harbour, and your haven of joy,
For so we will strive to make it, noble strangers,
Those virtues you have taught us by your deeds,
We futurely will strive to imitate.
And for the wrongs done to the hoped delights
Of your lost nights divorce, double the magazine
With which our larges should have swelled your ship.
A golden Girl thou art called,
And wench, be bold,
Thy lading back shall be with pearl and gold.

sp.speaker: Chor.
sp.p:
ImagineBesse and Spencer under sail:
But the intelligence of their great wealth,
Being bruited amongst the Merchants, comes to the ears
Of a French Pirate, who with two ships well rigged,
Way lays them in their voyage: long they fought,
And many slain on both sides; but the Frenchmen,
Proud of their hopeful conquest, boarding twice,
Are twice blown up, which adds courage to the English;
But to the Frenchmen fear: just as they buckled,
Spencer and Goodlack, with two proof Targets armed,
Into the French ship leap, and on the hatches,
There make a bloody slaughter: but at that instant,
The billows swelled, the winds grew high, and loud,
And as the soul and body use to part,
With no less force these lovers are divided,
He wafts to her, and she makes signs to him:
He calls, and she replies: - they both grow hoarse,
With shrieking out their last farewell. - now she swooned:
And sinks beneath the arms of Ruffman. Spencer,
Upon a Chest gets hold and safe arrives
In the Marquis of Farara's country: the like adventure
Chanced Goodlack, upon a Mast he pierces Italy,
Where these two Dukes were then at odds. Spencer is chosen
Farara's Champion: Mantua makes Goodlack his.
What happened them if you desire to know,
To cut off words, we will act it in dumb show.
The Dukes by them atoned, they graced and preferred,
Take their next way towards Florence. What of Besse,
Ruffman, and Clem becomes, must next succeed.
The seas to them like cruel proves, and wrecks
Their Negro on the coast of Florence, where
They wander up and down amongst the Bandittis.
More of their fortunes we will next pursue,
In which we mean to be as brief as true.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: All is lost.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Save these ourselves.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
For my part I have not so much left as a clean
Shirt.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
And Spencer too, had the seas left me him,
I should have thought them kind, but in his fate,
All wishes, fortunes, hopes of better days
Expire.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Spencer may live.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Aye, that he may, if it be but in a sea-water green
suit, as I was, among the haddocks.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
How many bitter plunges have I past,
Ere I could win my Spencer? who no sooner
Married, but quite divorced, possessed for some few days,
Then rent asunder, as soon a widow as I was a Bride:
This day the mistress of many thousands,
And a beggar now, not worth the clothes I wear.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
At the lowest ebb
The tides still flow, besides, being on the ground,
Lower we cannot fall.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Yes, into the ground, the grave.
Ruffman, would I were there; till then I never
Shall have true rest: I fain would know
What greater misery heaven can inflict, I have not yet
Endured: if there be such, I dare it, let it come.

sp.speaker: Band.
sp.p: Cease, and surprise the prisoners: thou art mine.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Villain, hands off, knowest thou whom thou offendest?

sp.speaker: Band.
sp.p: Bind her fast, and after captive him.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
I will rather die
Than suffer her sustain least injury.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: What is thy purpose?

sp.speaker: Band.
sp.p:
In all my travels, and my quest of blood,
I never encountered such a beauteous prize:
Heavens, if I thought you would accept his thanks
That trades in deeds of hell, I would acknowledge
Myself in debt to you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
What is thy intent,
Bold villein, that thou makest this preparation?

sp.speaker: Band.
sp.p: I intend to ravish thee.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
All goodness pardon me, and you blessed heavens,
Whom I too boldly challenged for a misery
Beyond my Spencers loss. What, rape intended?
I had not thought there had been such a mischief,
Devised for wretched woman: ravish me?
It is beyond shipwreck, poverty, or death:
It is a word invented first in hell,
And by the devils first spewed upon earth:
Man could not have invented to have given
Such letters sound.

sp.speaker: Band.
sp.p:
I trifle hours too long,
And now to my black purpose. Envious day,
Gaze with thy open eyes on this nights work,
For thus the Prologue to my lust begins.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Help, murther, rape, murther.

sp.speaker: Band.
sp.p: I will stop your mouth from bawling.

div2.stage: Enter Duke of Florence, and a train, and Merchant.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
This way the cry came: rescue for the Lady,
Hold thy desperate fury, and arm thyself
For my encounter.

sp.speaker: Band.
sp.p: Hell prevented.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Unbind that beauteous Lady, and pursue
The Ruffian; he that can bring his head shall have
A thousand crowns proposed for his reward:
He should be Captain of those bloody thieves,
That haunts our mountains, and of our dear subjects
Hath oft made outrage. Go, see this proclaimed.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Ere I, the happy wishes of my soul,
My orisons to heaven, or make free tender
Of a most bounden duty, grace my misery,
To let me know, unto what worthy person,
Of what degree or state, I owe the service
Of a most wretched life, lest in my ignorance,
I prove an heretic to all good manners,
And harshly so offend.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Fairest of thy sex, I need not question thine,
Because I read a nobleness in thy forehead;
But to resolve thee, know, I am styled, The Duke
Of Florence, and of this country Prince.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Then from my knees I fall flat on my face,
In bound obeisance.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Rise,
That earth is too base for such pure lips to kiss.
They should rather join with a Princes, as at first
Made for such use: nay, we will have it so.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p:
That Lady, if my memory be faithful
Unto my judgment, I should have seen ere now,
But where, what place, or in what country, now
I cannot call to mind.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Where were you bred?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: In England, royal Sir.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: In England?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
By what strange adventure then
Happened you on these coasts?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: By shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Then churlish were the waves to expose you to
Such danger. Whence disembark it you last?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: From Barbary.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: From Barbary? our Merchant, you came lately thence.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p:
It is she, I now remember her,
She did me a great courtesy, and I am proud,
Fortune, how ever enemy to her,
Has given me opportunity to make
A just requital.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
What occasion
Fair Lady, being of such state and beauty,
Drew you from your own country, to expose you
To so long travel.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p:
Mighty Sovereign,
Pardon my interruption, if I make bold
To put your grace in mind of an English Virgin,
So highly graced by mighty Mullisheg.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
A legend, worthy to be writ in gold,
Whose strangeness seemed at first to exceed belief;
And had not thy approved honesty
Commanded our attention, we should have doubted
That thou therein hadst much hyperbolical.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p:
What would your grace give,
To see that miracle of constancy,
She who relieved so many Christian captives,
Redeemed so many of the Merchants goods,
Begged of the king so many forfeitures,
Kept from the Galleys some, and some from slaughter,
She whom the king of Fesse never denied,
But she denied him love; whose chastity
Conquered his lust, and maugre his incontinence,
Made him admire her virtues.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
The report
Strikes us with wonder and amazement too:
But to behold the creature were a project,
Worthy a theatre of Emperors;
Nay, gods themselves to be spectators.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: Behold that wonder. Lady, know you me?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Not I, I can assure you, Sir.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p:
