I will give you instance then;
I was that Florentine:
Who being in Fesse; for a strange outrage there,
Six of my men were to the Galleys doomed:
But at your intercession to the king,
Freely released: for which, in this dejection,
I pray accept these thousand crowns, to raise
Your ruined fortunes.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: You are grateful, Sir, beyond my merit

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
I cannot blame great Fesse
To become enamoured on so fair a creature.
You had a friend much graced by that same Moor,
Whom, as our Merchant told us, you were espoused to
In the Court of Fesse, where is he?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I cannot speak it without tears.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Why, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: I cannot say he lives.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: How were you severed?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: It asks a sad relation.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
We will find a fitter time to hear it. But now,
Augment your griefs no further: on what coast
Pray, were you shipwrecked?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Upon these neighbouring shores; where all the wealth
I had from Barbary is perished in the sea.
I that this morn commanded half a million,
Have nothing now but this good merchants bounty.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
You are richer
In our high favour, than all the royalty,
Fesse could have crowned your peerless beauty with:
He gave you gold; but we your almost forfeit chastity.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: A gift above the wealth of Barbary.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Conduct this Lady to the City straight,
And bear this our signet to our treasurer,
Command for her ten thousand crowns immediately.
Next to our wardrobe, and what choice of habit
Best likes her, it is her own;
Only for all this grace, deign beauteous Lady,
That I may call you servant.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Pardon me, Sir,
You are a Prince, and I am here your vassal.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Merchant,
As you respect our favour see this done.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
What must my next fall be? I that this morning
Was rich in wealth and servants, and ere noon
Commanded neither: and next doomed to death;
Not death alone, but death with infamy.
But what is all this unto my Spencers loss?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
You to the City, we will pursue the chase.
Madam, be comforted, we will send, or see you;
All your fortunes are not extinct in shipwreck,
The land affords you better if you will be swayed by us.
As first you find us, we will be still the same:
Oft have I chased never found so fair a game.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Where are my Bashaws now? Let me see, what
shall I do? I have left my Mistress, where shall I have my
wages? she is papered by this: but if the Captain of the
Bandittis had had but that grace and honour that I had
when I was in Barbary, he would not have been so lusty.
She scaped drowning, which is the way of all fish, and by
this is gone the way of all flesh. My Lieutenant he is sure
cut to pieces among the Bandittis, and so had I been,
had not my Bakers legs stepped a little aside. My noble Captain
and Spencer, they are either drowned in the tempest,
or murthered by the Pirates, and none is left alive but I
Clem, poor Clem: but poor Clem, how wilt thou do now?
what trick have you to satisfy Colon, here in a strange
Country? It is not now with me as when Andrea lived.
Now I bethink me, I have a trade, and that, they say, will
stick by a man when his friends fail him: the City is hard
by, and I will see if I can be entertained to my old trade of
drawing wine: if it be but an under skinker, I care not,
better do so then like a prodigal feed upon husks and
acorns.
Well, if I chance to lead my life under some happy sign,
To my Countrymen still I will fill the best wine.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Wounded, but scaped with life: but Besses loss,
that is it that grieves me inward: ravished, perhaps, and
murthered. O, if Spencer and Goodlack survive, how
would they blame my cowardice? a thread spun, may be
untwined, but things in nature done, undone can never
be. She is lost, they are perished, they are happy in their
deaths, and I surviving left to the earth most miserable. No
means to raise myself? I met a Pursuivant even now, proclaiming
to the man could bring the head of the Bandittis
Captain, for his reward a thousand crowns: If not for
gain of gold, yet for he injured Besse, that shall be my next
task: What though I die?
Be this my comfort, that it chanced me well,
To perish by his hand by whom she fell.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Our Merchant, have you done to the English Lady
As we commanded, did she take the gold?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
After many complements, circumstances,
Modest refusals, sometimes with repulse,
I forced on her your bounty: Had you seen
What a bewitching art she strived to use,
Betwixt denial, and disdain; contempt and thankfulness,
You would have said, that out of a mere scorn
To accept your gift, she expressed such gratitude,
As would demand a double donative.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
If it has done it, it shall be doubled straight,
Arising thence unto an infinite,
If she will but grant us love. How for her habit?

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p:
With an enforced will, wilful constraint,
And a mere kind of glad necessity,
She put it on but to lament the death
Of her lost husband.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Why, is he lost?

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: By all conjectures never to be found.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
The less her hope is to recover him,
The more our hopes remains to conquer her:
Bear her from us this jewel, and withal
Provide a banquet, bid her leave all mourning,
This night in person we will visit her.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: I shall.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Withal more gold.
And if thou canst by way of conference,
Get from her how she stands affected towards us:
It shall not be the furthest way about
To thy preferment and our special favour.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p:
The two bold Dukes of Mantua and Farara,
after many bloody garboils have entered league: and within
these two days mean to visit Florence, to make your
Court a witness of their late concluded amity.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
We will receive them,
As Princes that in this would honour us.

sp.speaker: Mess.
sp.p: These letters will speak further.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Bear them straight
Unto our Secretary, and withal, give order,
That all our Court may shine in gold and pearl,
They never could have come in a happier season,
Than when the great and high magnificence,
Without suspect we would have shown to her,
Will be accounted honour done to them.
In fates despite,
we will not lose the honour of this night.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Farara was exceeding bountiful.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
So was the Duke of Mantua. Had we staid
Within their confines, we might even till death
Have lived in their high favour.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
O, but Captain,
What would their Dukedoms gain me without Besse,
Or all the world to enjoy it without her:
Each passage of content or pleasing fortune,
When I record she has no part in it,
Seems rather as an augmentation
Of a more great disease.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
This be your comfort, that by this
She is best part of her way for England, whither
She is richly bound, then where she is most hopeless
Of this your safety,
With your survival to receive us gladly
With an abundant treasure.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
But for that,
I had sunk ere this beneath the weight of war.
And choosed an obscure death, before the glory
Of a renowned soldier. But we are now
As far as Florence onward of our way,
Were it best that we made tender of our service
To the grand Duke?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
It is the greatest benefits of all our travels, to
see foreign Courts, and to discourse their fashions: let
us by no means neglect that duty.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Where were we best to lodge?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Hard by is a Tavern, let us first drink there, and
after make inquiry who is the best host for strangers.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Come ho, where be these Drawers?

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p:
Gentlemen, I draw none myself, but I will send
some.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Welcome Gentlemen. Score a quart.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: No, no, I am an ass, a very animal, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Why dost thou bear the wine back, the slave
thinks belike we have no money?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
What dost thou think us to be such cashiered soldiers
that we have no cash. Tush, it cannot be he.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: How should he come here, set down the wine.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I will, I will, sir. Score a quart of - Tricks,
mere phantasms. Shall I draw wine to shadows? so I might
run on the score, and find no substance to pay for it.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Left we not him a shipboard on his voyage towards
England with my

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: With Besse, true, Sirrah, set down the wine.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Some Italian Mountebanks, upon my life, mere
juggling.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Upon my life it is Clem.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: Ca, Ca, Cap. Captain? Master Spencer?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: I am Clem.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: And I am Spencer.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And I Goodlack, but cannot think thee Clem.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Yes, I am Clem of Foy, the Bashaw of Barbary,
who from a Courtier of Fesse, am turned a Drawer in Florence:
but let me clear my eyes better; now I know you
to be the same whose throats the Pirates would have cut,
and have spoiled your drinkings.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
O, tell us, and be brief in thy relation,
What happened you, after the sudden tempest
Severed our ships? or what is become of Besse?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Where did our Negro touch?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I will give you a touch, take it as you will: The
Negro and all that was in her was wrecked on the coast of
of Florence, her, and all the wealth that was in her, all
drowned in the bottom of the sea.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
No matter for the riches, where is she, worth
More than ship or goods?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Where is Ruffman? for thou we see art safe.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Nay speak, where is Besse?
How my heart quails within me?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
She, Ruffman, and I were all cast ashore safe,
like so many drowned Rats, where we were no sooner
landed, but we were set upon by the Bandittis; where
she was bound to a tree, and ready to be ravished by the
Captain of the Out-laws.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: O, worse than shipwreck could be.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I see Ruffman half cut in pieces with rescuing her,
but whether the other half be alive or no, I cannot tell.
For my one part, I made shift for one, my heels doing
me better service than my hands: and coming to the
City, having no other means to live by, got me to my old
trade to draw wine, where I have the best wine in Florence
for you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Ravished.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And Ruffman slain.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
O, hard news:
It frets all my blood, and strikes me stiff with
Horror and amazement.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
It strikes me
Into a marble statue, for with such
I have like sense and feeling.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Tell me Captain,
Wilt thou give me leave at length to despair
And kill myself: I will disclaim all further
Friendship with thee, if thou persuadest me live.
Ravished!

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Perhaps attempted but prevented,
Will you before you know the utmost certainty,
Destroy yourself?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
What is this world? what is man? are we created
Out of flint or iron, that we are made to bear this?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Comfort, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Your only way is to drink wine if you be in
grief, for that is the only way, the old proverb says, to
comfort the heart.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Hark where we lie, and I prithee Clem let us hear
from thee, but now leave us.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I will make bold inquire you out, and if you
want money (as many travellers may) as long as I have either
credit, wages, or any coin in the world, you shall not
want, as I am a true Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Let us stand aside and suffer these Gallants pass,
that with their state take a whole street before them.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Our Coach, stay, we will back some half hour hence,
Only conduct this Lady to her lodging.
Ha, started you, Sweet, whence fetched
You that sigh. Our train lead on,
We have other business now to think upon.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Sure this was some great Lady.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
But observed you not this jewel that she
cast me? it is a rich one.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Believe me, worthy your wearing.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
What might she be to whom I am thus bound?
I am here a stranger, never till this day
Beheld I Florence, nor acquaintance, friend:
Especially of Ladies.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
By their train,
The man that did support her by the arm
Was of some special note; and she a Lady
Nobly descended. Why should she throw you this,
Being a mere stranger?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
There is some mystery in it,
If we could find the depth of it, sure there is.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Perhaps some newly fallen in love with you,
Now at first sight, and hurled that as a favour.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p:
Yet neither of us
had or the wit or sense to enquire her name:
I will wear it openly and see if any
Will challenge it: the way to know her best.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: And I would so.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I will truce a while with sorrow for my Besse,
Till I find the event.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
And at best leisure
Tender our service to the Duke,
Whom same reports to be a bounteous prince,
And liberal to all strangers.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
It is decreed -
But howsoever his favours he impart,
My Besses loss will still sit near my heart.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
This honour you have done me, worthy Princes,
In leaving of your Courts to visit me,
We reckon as a trophy of your loves,
And shall remain a future monument,
Of a more firm and perfect amity.

sp.speaker: Mant.
sp.p:
To you, as to the greatest, most honoured,
And most esteemed Prince of Italy,
After a tedious opposition,
And much effuse of blood, this Prince and I,
Late reconciled, make a most happy tender
Of our united league.

sp.speaker: Farar.
sp.p:
Selecting you
A royal witness of this union,
Which to express, we come to feast with you,
To sport and revel, and in full largess,
To spread our royal bounty through your Court.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
What neither letters nor Ambassadors,
Soliciting by factions, or by friends,
Heavens hand hath done by your more calmer temper.

sp.speaker: Mant.
sp.p:
All resistals,
Quarrels, and ripping up of injuries,
Are smothered in the ashes of our wrath,
Whose fire is now extinct.

sp.speaker: Ferar.
sp.p:
Which who so kindles,
Let him be held a new Herostratus,
Who was so hated throughout Ephesus,
They held it death to name him.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Nobly spoke.
And now confederate Princes, you shall find,
By our rich entertainment, how we esteem
Your friendship. Speak, have we no Ladies here
To entertain these princes?

sp.speaker: Mant.
sp.p:
Methinks I spy one beauty in this place,
Worth all the sights that I have seen before.
I think, survey the spacious world abroad,
You scarce can find her equal.

sp.speaker: Farar.
sp.p:
Had not wonder,
And deep amazement curbed my speech in,
I had forestalled this Prince in approbation
Of her compareless beauty.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Taste her Princes.
This surfeits me, and ads unto my love,
That they should thus admire her.

sp.speaker: Matua.
sp.p:
Beauteous Lady,
It is not my least honour to be first
In this most wished solicit.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I stand a statue,
And cannot move but by another's will,
And as I am commanded.

sp.speaker: Farar.
sp.p:
I should have wrestled for priority,
But that I hold it as a blessing,
To take off that kiss which he so late laid on.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Now tell me Princes,
How do you like my judgment in the choice
Of a fair mistress?

sp.speaker: Mant.
sp.p: You shall choose for me.

sp.speaker: Farar.
sp.p:
More happy in this beauty, I account you,
Than in your richest treasure.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Were it not clouded over
With such a melancholy sadness, I would
Not change it for the wealth of Italy.
Sweet, cheer this brow whereon no frown can sit,
But it will ill become you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Sir, I bleed.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Ha, bleed?
I would not have a sad and ominous fate
Hang over thee for a million:
Perhaps it is custom with you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I have observed
Even from my childhood, never fell from hence
One crimson drop, but either my greatest enemy,
Or my dearest friend was near.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Why, we are here,
First to thy side thy dearest friend on earth.
If that be all, fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Pardon, Sir,
Both modesty and manners pleads for me
And I must needs retire.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Our train attend her,
Let her have all observance. By my royalty,
I would not have her taste the least disaster
For more than we can promise.

sp.speaker: Ferar.
sp.p:
You have only showed us a rich Jewel, Sir,
And put it in a casket.

sp.speaker: Mant.
sp.p:
Of what country,
Fortune, or birth doth she proclaim herself?
For by her garb and language we may guess,
She was not bred in Florence.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Seat you Princes, I will tell you a strange project.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I have walked the streets, but find not any that
will make challenge of this jewel. Captain, now we will
try the Court.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Beware of these Italians,
They are by nature jealous and revengeful,
Not sparing the most basest opportunity,
That may procure your danger.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p:
Innocence
Is bold and cannot fear. But see the Duke,
We will tender him the solemnest reverence
Of travellers and strangers. Peace, prosperity,
And all good fates attend your royalty.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Behold, we are two poor English Gentlemen,
Whom travel hath enforced through your Dukedom,
As next way to our country, prostrate you
Our lives and service: it is not for reward,
Or hope of gain we make this tender to you,
But our free loves.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
That which so freely comes,
How can we scorn? what are you Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Mant.
sp.p: I will speak for this.

sp.speaker: Farar.
sp.p:
And I for him,
Well met renowned Englishman
Here in the Court of Florence: this was he,
Great Duke, whom fame hath for his valour blazoned;
Not only through Mantua,
But through the spacious bounds of Italy,
Where it was shown.

sp.speaker: Ferar.
sp.p:
Hath fame been so injurious to thy merit,
That this great Court is not already filled
With rumour of their matchless chivalry.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
If these be they, as by their outward semblance,
They promise not much less: fame hath been harbinger
To speak their praise before hand. Noble Gentlemen,
You have much graced our Court; we thank you for it:
And though no way according to your merits,
Yet will we strive to cherish such brave spirits.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
The acceptance of our smallest service, Sir,
Is bounty above gold: we are poor Gentlemen,
And though we cannot, gladly would deserve.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
It has pleased these princes to bestow on us
Too great a character: and gild our praises
Far above our deserts.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
That is but your modesty.
English Gentlemen, let fame speak for you.

sp.speaker: Farar.
sp.p:
Gentlemen of England, we pardon you all duty,
We accept you as our friends and our companions:
Such you are, and such we do esteem you.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p:
Mighty Prince,
Such boldness wants excuse.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Come we will have it so.
Amazement, can it be? Sure it is the self same jewel
I gave the English Lady: more I view it,
More it confirms my knowledge: now is no time
To question it, once more renowned Englishmen,
Welcome to us and to these Princes.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Can any man show me the great Duke of
Florence?

sp.speaker: March.
sp.p: Behold the Prince.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Deign, thou renowned Duke, to cast thy eyes
Upon a poor dejected Gentleman,
Whom fortune hath dejected even to nothing.
I have nor meat nor money; these rags are all my riches;
Only necessity compels me claim
A debt owing by you.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
By us?
Let us know the sum, and how the debt accrues.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
You have proclaimed to him could bring the head
Of the Bandetties' Captain, for his reward,
A thousand crowns. Now I being a Gentleman,
A traveller, and in want, made this my way
To raise my ruined hope: I singled him,
Fought with him hand to hand, and from his bloody shoulders
Lopped this head.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Boldly and bravely done: what ever thou be
Thou shalt receive it from our treasury.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
You show yourself as fame reports you,
A bounteous Prince, and liberal to all strangers.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
From what country
Do you claim your birth?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: From England, royal Sir!

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
These bold Englishmen,
I think are all composed of spirit and fire,
The element of earth hath no part in them.

sp.speaker: Mant.
sp.p:
If, as you say, from England, we retain
Some of your Countrymen; know you these Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Let me no longer live in ecstasy,
This wonder will confound me: Noble friends,
Bootless it were to ask you why, because
I find you here. Illustrious Duke, you owe
Me nothing now, to show me these, is reward
Beyond what you proclaimed: the rest I pardon.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
What these are we know,
And what thou art we need not question much,
That head though mute can speak it.
Princes, once more receive our royal welcome.
O, but the jewel: but of that at leisure
Now we cannot stay. Our train, lead on.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
O, that we three so happily should meet,
And want the fourth.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
I left her in the hands of rape and murther,
Whence, except some deity,
It was not in the power of man to rescue her;
How ever, a good office I have done her,
Which even in death her soul will thank me for,
Revenged her on that villain.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
It hath expressed the nobleness of thy Spirit.
For it we still shall owe thee.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
But what adventure hath preferred you
And brought you thus in grace?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
You shall hereafter
Partake of that at large. But leaving this discourse,
With our joint persuasions let us strive to comfort him,
That is nothing but discomfort.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
Would I had brought him news of that rare virtue.
Yet you have never heard of our late shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Clem reported it.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: How Clem, where is he?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: He has got a service hard by, and draws wine.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
His master may well trust him with his maids,
For since the Bashaws gelded him, he has learned
To run exceeding nimbly.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p:
Sir, it is to you, I take it,
My message is directed.
The Duke would have some conference with you, but
it must be in private.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I am his servant, still at his command.
Where shall us meet anon.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: At Clems.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Where we will make a due relation of all our
desperate fortunes.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: It is concluded.

div2.stage: Enter Duke of Florence and Spencer.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
I cannot rest till I am fully resolved
About this jewel. Sir, we sent to stay you,
And wean you some small season from your friends:
And you above the rest, because your presence
Doth promise good discourse.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Sir, I am all yours.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: How long hath been your sojourn here in Florence?

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p: Two days, no more.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Have you since your arrival
Retained no beauteous Mistress? Pardon me,
Sir, that I am come thus near you.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p:
On my soul
Not any, royal Sir.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Think it my love that I presume thus far
To question you. Have you observed no Lady
Of special note, courted or discoursed with any
Within these two days.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Upon my honour, none.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
You are a soldier and a Gentleman,
And should speak all truth.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: If otherwise, I should disclaim my gentry.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
I believe you, Sir. You have a rich jewel here,
Worthy a Princes wearing: it were not modesty
To ask how you came by it, or from whom.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Nor can I, Sir, resolve you, if you did:
But it was cast me by a Lady, of whom
As then I took small notice of, my mind
Being troubled.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: It is even so.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Perhaps your grace by knowing of this jewel,
May know the beauteous flinger, and so
You might engage me deeply to acquaint me with her,
To prove her grateful debtor.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
No such thing,
You know none in this City?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Worse than scorn,
Or foul disgrace befall me if I know
Any you can call woman.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Be not moved,
I spoke but this in sport. Sure this strange Lady,
Casting her eye upon this Gentleman,
Grew straight if him enamoured, which makes her
Keep off from my embraces: but I will sound all,
Yet my own wrongs prevent. Sir, I staid you,
But to another purpose, to commit
A weighty secret to you.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Were it of millions,
I would prove your faithful steward.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
I have a Mistress that I tender dearer
Than mine own eyes. Observe me, dearer Sir,
Whom neither courtship moves, favours can work,
Nor no preferment tempt.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
How rich were he
Could call himself lord of such a jewel.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
My entreaties, friends, persuasions, importunities
Of my chaste Ladies cannot prevail at all.
Now would I chose a stranger, selecting thee,
To bear to her these few lines which contain
The substance of my mind.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p: And Sir, I shall.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
In thy aspect
I read a fortune that should destine me
To strange felicities. Wilt thou be faithful?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: As to my soul.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
But thou shalt swear before thou undertakest it,
(Though I suspect not falsehood in thy visage)
Not once to cast on her an amorous look,
Speak to her no familiar syllable,
Not to embrace her, nor to kiss her hand,
Nor her free lip by no means.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Well, I swear.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
But that is not all,
Swear by thy faith and thy religion.
Not to taste the least small favour for thyself,
Touch or come near her bosom; for, fair stranger,
I love her above measure, and that love
Makes me thus jealous.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
By my honesty,
Faith, and religion, without free release
From your own lips, all this will I perform.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
And so return the richest Englishman,
That ever pierced our Dukedom. Instantly
Thou shalt about thy task.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
You have tired our ears with your long discourse
Leave us to rest.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: Dream on your best desires.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
If at some half hour hence you visit us,
We shall be free for language.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: Soft rest with you.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
If my soft sleeps presents me any shadow
O, let it be my Spencers, him whom waking
I cannot see, I may in dreams perhaps
Converse with, my sudden bleeding and my drowsiness,
Should not presage me good: pray heaven the Duke
Prove loyal to mine honour: howsoever
Death will end all: and I presume on this
It is way to Spencer, and my haven of bliss.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
What beauty should this be, on whom the Duke
Is grown so jealous: sure it is some rare piece;
He told me she was fairer than I could either
Judge, Or yet imagine.
Would Besse were here to wager beauties with her,
For all my hopes in England. This is the Chamber:
Ha, thus far off she seems to promise well,
I will take a nearer and more free survey,
This taper shall assist me: fail my eyes?
Or meet I nothing else but prodigies?
O heavens, it is my Besse; O, sudden rapture!
Let me retire to more considerate thoughts.
What should I think, but presently to wake her?
And being mine, to seize her where I find her.
O, but mine oath, that I should never, never
Lie with her being my wife, nor kiss her, touch her,
Speak to her one familiar syllable.
Can oaths bind thus? My honesty, faith, and
Religion are all engaged, there is no dispense for them.
And yet in all this conflict to remember
How the Duke praised her virtue, chastity,
And constancy, whom nothing could corrupt,
Ads to my joys. But on the neck of this,
It lays a double torture on my life.
First to forswear, then leave so fair a wife.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I am all distraction. In my sleep
I saw him, could I but behold him waking.
That were a heaven. Ha, do I dream still?
Or was I born to see
Nothing but strange illusions. Spencer: Love.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p: I am neither.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Thou hast his shape, his gate, his face, his language:
Only these words of thine and strange behaviour,
Never came from him. Let me embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Then kiss me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Yet speak me fair.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: Look on me.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I must not, I will not, fare thee well:
Yet first read that.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I have read too much already within thy change
of looks.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
O me my oath;
I would chop off this right hand to cancel it.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: But if not now, when then?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Not kiss me?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Not fold me in thine arms?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Not.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Nor cast a gracious look upon thy Besse?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: I dare not.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: No never.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: O, I shall die.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
She faints, and yet I dare not for my oath
Once to support her. Dies before mine eyes.
And yet I must not call her back to life.
Where is the Duke? some help, no Ladies nigh?
Are you all, all asleep or dead,
There is no more noise in Court?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Ha, what is the business, noble friend, what news
How speed you with my Mistress?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
You may see there on the ground, half
In the grave already. So fare you well,
What grief mine is, those that love best can tell.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Support her. Speak love, look up divinest Mistress.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
You said you would not speak, nor look, nor
touch your Besse.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Who I?
By all my hopes I never had such a thought.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: O, I mistook.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Why do you look so ghastly about the room?
Whom does your eyes enquire for?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Nothing, nay, nobody.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Hath some new love possessed him, and excluded
Me from his bosom? can it be possible?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: All leave the chamber.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
But I will be so revenged as never woman was:
I will be a president to all wives hereafter,
How to pay home their proud neglectful husbands;
It is in my way, I have power, and I will do it.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: What is it offends you?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: It is you have done it.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: We?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
If you be the Prince:
There is but one man I hate above all the world,
And you have sent him to torment me here.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: What satisfaction shall I make thee for it?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
This, and this only; If you have any interest
In him, or power above him: if you be a Prince
In your own country, have command and rule
In your own dominions, freely resign his person
And his state solely to my disposure.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
But whence grows
The ground of such inveterate hate?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
All circumstance to omit,
He, and only he ravished me from my country,
He was the cause of all my afflictions,
Tempests, shipwreck, fears. I never had just cause
Of care and grief but he was author of it.
Speak, is he mine?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
What interest I can claim, either by oath
Or promise, thou art Commandress of.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Then I am yours;
And tomorrow in the public view of all
The stranger Princes, Courtiers, and Ladies,
I will express myself. This night I entreat
I may repose myself in my own lodging
For private meditations.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
What we have promised,
Is in our purpose most irrevocable,
And so we hope is yours.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: You may presume, my lord.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Conduct this Lady to her chamber,
Let her have all observance: we will lay
Our strict command on him, lest he should leave
Our City before our summons, it is tomorrow, then,
Shall happy thee, make us most blessed of men.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Now shall I quite him home,
The ingrate shall know,
It is above patience to be injured so.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: Will you walk Lady, or take your coach?

sp.speaker: Besse
sp.p:
That we the streets more freely may survey,
We will walk along.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Let me see, three quarts, two pottles, one gallon
and a pint, one pint, two quarts more, then I have my
load: thus are we that are under-journeymen put to it.
O the fortune of the seas; never did any man that marries
a whore, so cast himself away, as I had been like in the
last tempest: yet nothing vexes me so much, that after all
my travels, no man that meets me but may say, and say
very truly, I am now no better than a pot companion.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
That should be Clem my man, give me some gold,
Here, Sirrah, drink this to the health
Of thy old Mistress. Usher on,
We have more serious things to think upon.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Mistress Besse, Mistress Elizabeth, it is she: ha,
gold: hence pewter pots, I will be a pewter porter no longer:
my Mistress turned Gallant, and shall I do nothing but run
up stares and down stares with, Anon, anon, Sir? no, I
have gold, and anon will be as gallant as the proudest of
them. Shall I stand at the Bar to bar any man's casting that
drinks hard? no, I will send these pots home by some porter
or other, put myself into a better habit, and say, The
case is altered; then will I go home to the bush where I
drew wine, and buy out my time, and take up my Chamber,
be served in pomp by my fellow prentices:
I will presently thither,
Where I will flaunt it in my Cap and my Feather.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
You tell us of the strangest wonderment that
ever came within the compass of my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: I tell you but what is true.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
It cannot find example. Did you leave her
those extremities of passion?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: I think dying, or the next way to death.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
To cheer you,
The Dukes own witness of her constancy,
And virtue, armed against all temptations,
Part of your griefs should lessen.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Rather friend,
Augment my passions, to be forced to lose,
And quite abjure so sweet a bedfellow.
O, it breeds more distraction.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Were it my cause,
I would to the Duke and claim her, beg for justice,
And through the populous court clamour my wrongs,
If he detain her from you.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
But my oath
Ties me from that, I have quite abjured her,
I have renounced her freely, cast her off,
Disclaimed her quite: I can no more
Interest claim in her, than Goodlack
Thou, or Ruffman thou.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
It is most strange, let us examine all our brains
How this may be avoided.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
How now Clem, you loiter here, the house is full
of guests, and you are extremely called for.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
You are deceived my Lieutenant, I will assure you,
you speak to as good a man as myself: Do you want any
money?

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: Canst thou lend me any?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Look, I am the lord of these mines, of these
Indies.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: How camest thou by them?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
A delicate sweet Lady, meeting me in the street,
like an Ass groaning under my heavy burthen, and being
enamoured of my good parts, gave me this gold: if
you think I lie, examine all these pots, whose mouths, if
they could speak, would say as much in my behalf. But
if you want any money, speak in time, for if I once turn
Courtier again, I will scorn my poor friends, look scurvily
upon my acquaintance, borrow of all men, be beholding
to any man, and acknowledge no man: and my Motto
shall be, Base is the man that pays.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: But Clem, how camest thou by this gold?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
News, news, though not the lost sheep, yet the
lost shrew is found, my Mistress, Mistress Elizabeth, it is she,
she meeting me in the street, seeing I had a pot or two too
much, gave me ten pounds in a purse to pay for it, Ecce Signum.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
The Duke hath summoned your appearance, Gentlemen,
And lays his power of love, not of command,
To visit him in Court.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I am put into the number too, if he be a tall
man, tell him we will attend his highness.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Fellow, my language was not aimed at you.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: But Sir, I will make bold to come at first bidding.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
Sir, your reward stays for you at Court,
For bringing of the outlawed Captains head,
There is order taken for it from the treasury.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: The Duke is just and royal. We will attend you.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
And I will go furnish myself with some better accoutrements,
and I will be with you to bring presently.

sp.speaker: Mant.
sp.p:
There is not in your looks renowned Florence,
That summer's calm, and sweet alacrity
That was wont there to shine, a winters storm
Sits threatening on your discontented brow.
May we desire the cause.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Which you shall know.
Princes, the fierce and bloody moors, have late
Committed outrage on our seas, especially,
One mighty Bashaw, against whom we have sent
Petro Deventuro, one of our best Sea Captains,
And, till we hear of his success, we are bard
Of much content.

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p:
My lord, good news, Petro Deventuro is returned
With happy victory, and many noble prisoners,
And humbly lays his conquest at your feet.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Petro, welcome.
This thy service shall not die unrewarded. Freely relate
The manner of thy Sea fight.

sp.speaker: Petro.
sp.p:
Then thus, great Duke.
This noble Bashaw: noble I must call him,
For he deserves that worthy attribute,
Did lord over these our seas, appointed well;
Laden with many a rich and golden spoil,
Not weak to us in number; being in ken,
We had him and his Galleys straight in chase:
He never set sail or fled: afar our ordnance played;
Coming more near, our muskets and our small shot,
Like showers of hail begun the slaughter;
There this Bashaw then perceiving straight
That he must either yield or die: his Scimitar
He pointed to his breast, thinking thereon
To perish, had not my coming staid him.

sp.speaker: Ioffer.
sp.p:
Nor think, bold Christian,
That I can commend, or thank thee for it,
For who that is noble will not prize brave death
Before a slavish bondage: had I died
By mine own hand, it had been a soldiers pride.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Although a prisoner captive and a Moor,
Yet use him like the noblest of his nation.
And now withdraw with him, till we
Determine of his ransom.

div2.stage: Enter Merchant and Besse: also Spencer, Ruffman, Goodlack.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: Way there for the Dukes Mistress.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Ha, the Dukes Mistress, said he:

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: It was harsh.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Keep off, we would have no such rubs as these,
Trouble our way? but have them swept aside,
A company of base companions, to do no reverence
To a Princes Mistress.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: Hear you that?

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: Give back, you trouble the presence.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
This cannot be Besse, but some Fury hath stolen
her shape.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: It seems strange.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: But unto me most horrid.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Great Duke, I come to keep my promise with you,
if you keep your word with me.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
These kind regrets are unto me more welcome
Than my late victory got at Sea:
Will it please you take your seat?

sp.speaker: Merc.
sp.p: Is not yon Spencer, and that the Captain of the Negro?

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: What shall we next behold?

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Yet are you mine?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
From all the world, great Florence, witness this,
You never had yet a voluntary kiss.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p: 'Sfoot I could tear my hair off.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Second your kindness, let these Princes see
Your tempting lips solely belongs to me.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
There is one again, it surfeits me above measure,
To be a Princes darling, and choice treasure.

sp.speaker: Spencer.
sp.p:
Hold me Goodlack, or I shall break out,
Into some dangerous outrage.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
Show in this your wisdom, and quite suppress
your fury.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Princes, I fear you have mistook yourselves
In these two strangers, for I have little hope
To find them worthy your great character.

sp.speaker: Mant.
sp.p:
There must be great presumption that must
force belief to that.

sp.speaker: Farar.
sp.p:
Nay more than presumptions, proofs,
Or they will win small credit.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
You had from us Lady, a costly jewel,
It cost ten thousand crowns, speak, can you show it?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I kept it chary
As mine own heart, because it came from you;
But hurrying through the street, some cheating fellow,
Snatched it from my arm, therefore my suit is
With whomsoever the jewel may be found,
The slave may die.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
His sentence thine, we never will revoke it.
Our Merchant, search all our Courtiers and such
Strangers as are within our Court.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p:
Here is one of no mean lustre that this Gentleman
wears in his hat.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Reach it the Lady.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p:
This cannot be Besse Bridges, but some Medusa,
Changed into her lively portraiture.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Princes, the thief is found: what ever he be
That is guilty of this felony, I beg
That I may be his sentencer.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
If you have any interest in his blood,
His oaths or vows, freely resign them, him,
And all at my dispose.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Have we not done it?

sp.speaker: Farar.
sp.p:
Who can with the least honour speak for him,
The theft being so apparent?

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
Now if she should challenge me with the purse
she gave me, and hang me up for my labour, I should curse
the time that ever I was a courtier.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
Let me descend, and ere I judge the Felon,
Survey him first. It is pity, for it seems
He hath an honest face. The word was never.

sp.speaker: Goodl.
sp.p: What Besse, forget yourself?

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
An indifferent proper man, and take these courses.
You said you would not speak, nor look upon, nor touch your
Besse.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
I could be a new Sinon and betray
A second Troy, rather than suffer this.

sp.speaker: Besse
sp.p:
Good outward parts, but in a foreign clime
Shame your own country. Never think of that.

sp.speaker: Spencer
sp.p:
I fear my heart will break,
It doth so struggle for eruption forth.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: When do you speak his sentence, Lady?

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p: You will confirm it what ever it be.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: As we are Prince we will.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p: Set forth the prisoner.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: Stand forward Englishman.

sp.speaker: Besse
sp.p:
Then hear thy doom, I give thee back thy life,
And in thy arms throw a most constant wife;
If Thou hast rashly sworn, thy oaths are free,
Thou art mine by gift, I give myself to thee.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Lady, we understand not this.

sp.speaker: Bess.
sp.p:
Shall I make it plain?
This is, great Duke, my husband,
Whose virtues even the barbarous Moors admired.
This the man for whom a thousand dangers I have endured,
Of whom the best approved Chroniclers,
Might write a golden legend.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p:
My lord, I know that Gentleman
For Spencer, and her husband, for mine eyes
Saw them espoused in Fesse: that Gentleman,
As I take it, was Captain of the Negro,
The other his Lieutenant.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p: And do not you know me?

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.p: Not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clem.
sp.p:
I am Bashaw of Barbary, by the same token I
sold certain precious stones to purchase the place.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
Lady, you told us he was the author
Of all your troubles, cares, and fears.

sp.speaker: Besse.
sp.p:
I told true, his love was cause of all,
It drew me from my Country in his quest,
When I despaired: and finding him in Fesse,
O do but think great Duke if ever you loved,
What might have bought him from you.
Had my Spencer been an Euridice,
I would have played the Orpheus,
And found him out in hell.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
We now perceive,
The cause of all these errors his unkindness,
Grounded on his rash oath, which we release;
And all those virtues, honours, and renowns,
Which even the barbarous Moors seemed to admire,
We will dignify and raise their suffrage higher,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Florence is honourable.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Bring in the Bashaw, call Venturo forth.

sp.speaker: Ioffer
Spenc.
sp.p:
Bashaw Ioffer?
Leave my embraces, Besse, for I of force am cast
Into his arms. My noble friend?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
I know you not, and I could wish you did not
know me, now I am a prisoner, a wretch, a captive, and
such a one as I would not have my friends to know. I pray
stand off.

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
Because you are in durance,
Should I not know you? no:
For then the noblest minds should friends best know.
Have you forgot me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
No; were I in freedom and my princely honours,
I should then be proud to call you Spencer,
And my friend, but now

sp.speaker: Spenc.
sp.p:
An English virtue thou shalt try,
That for my life once didst not fear to die.
That for his noble office done to me,
Embrace him Besse, dear Goodlack, and the rest,
Whilst to this Prince I kneel. This was the Bashaw,
King Mullisheg made him great Viceroy of Argiers.
I know not, Prince, how he is fallen so low,
But if myself, my friends, and all my fortunes
May redeem him home, unto my naked skin
I will sell myself: and if my wealth
Will not amount so much, I will leave myself in hostage.

sp.speaker: Farar.
sp.p:
It is the part
Of a most noble friend.

sp.speaker: Mant.
sp.p: And in these times worthy admiration

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
I wonder not the Moors so graced this nation,
If all the English equal their virtues.
For this brave Stranger so endeared to thee,
Pass to thy country ransomless and free.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: Royal in all things is the duke of Florence.

sp.speaker: Ioff.
sp.p:
Such honour is not found in Barbary.
The virtue in these Christians hath converted me,
Which to the world I can no longer smother,
Accept me then a Christian and a brother.

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p:
Princes,
These unexpected novelties,
Shall add unto the high solemnity
Of your best welcome. Worthy Englishman,
And you, the mirror of your sex and nation,
Fair English Elizabeth, as well for virtue
As admired beauty, we will give you cause, ere
You depart our Court, to say great Fesse
Was either poor, or else not bountiful.
Bashaw, we will honour your conversion,
With all due rites. But for you beauteous Lady,
Thus much in your behalf we do proclaim,
The fairest Maid were patterned in her life,
So fair a Virgin, and so chaste a wife.
